description:
Re:10100197398
The Code is clear
Garbage put out for collection in "plastic bags" shall not be less than 3 mils in thickness...
Thin kitchen type plastic trash bags (are not) even 1/3rd of the acceptable thickness to prevent rodents from foraging through them.
And therefore are not acceptable by the letter of the law regarding this Code.
Please read the Code and clarify.
If we are serious about fixing the rodent problem then we need to truly start enforcing this rule going into the new year.
It will create immense improvements City wide for the quality of life for the citizens of This Great City.
The Code/Law is written in the pic I am sending. (In the middle of rule (1)

description:
Re: case # 101001973988
You noted that "the bags in the photo are ok"
In the photo you can clearly see the rat that just crawled out of one of the bags he's been foraging through... (these bags are only .8mil in thickness (that is less than 1mil) 
and (((I believe I was quoted that bags left out for pick up have to be at least 1.5-3mil in thickness!? (That is at least twice the thickness) of these "thin kitchen type bags"
The Code is explicit in this for good reason.
To help prevent rodents from shredding through them throughout the night while they are left out for next morning pick up.
1.5-3 mil construction type plastic bags are the Proper sufficient thickness for un-contained garbage left out for pick up.
Please help to educate the Constituents of This Great City as to the actual "letter of the Law" so to speak and please print the actual Code regarding the proper, "decent" thickness of '"rodent proof" plastic sufficient to be left out for hours overnight.
The bags in the above photo are "NOT" 2pl as according to Code., so when did the Code change? and what is the written Code actually state in terms of "thickness" of the plastic (bag) that is deemed acceptable according to said written Code?

status_notes: Case Noted. any questions about publishing codes please contact director tankle at 617-635-4885.
description:
Re:101001973988
Anyone that actually cares about getting a handle on the rodent infestation in our neighborhoods can clearly see that these thin, less than 1 mil in thickness are not sufficient means of leaving waste out for pick up.
It's very easy to tell the difference 
No measuring with calipers or other devices are needed.
The thicker the plastic the more resistant it is to tearing and less likely to bring rodent to the area.
When we can do better yet we chose not to it affects everyone else.
Please cite the code regarding the actual thickness of plastic bags deemed appropriate for curbside pick up.
These are important matters to people that care.
Thank you very much in advance for helping to clear this up with actual facts.
We appreciate all the important work of The Mayors Office and Boston 311.
Sincerely
Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays

Clarification please, on what is acceptable by code in regards to the (thickness of plastic bags) that we the people consider appropriate to leave out "uncontained" for up to 12+ hours at a time on the street for rodents to shred through before they are picked up and when they are picked up lots of detritus spills out from the "thin kitchen type bags" that have been easily shredded through throughout the night by the ever growing rodent population.
If we are serious about keeping the rats away then we need to be much more vigilant when it comes to educating our community as well as those that we entrust with enforcing the very codes that are written to protect the people of This Great City.
(((Kitchen type trash bags are less than (read) less than 1 mil)))
Kitchen type bags are not sufficient in helping to quell the rodent problem, it only encourages them to forage through them for food.
Heavy duty black Construction type, 2ply bags are (1.5-3 mils thick). These are required by code.

description:
It's actually very easy to tell the difference between very thin "kitchen type" bags that are less than 1 mil, that are like wet tissue for rats to shred through foraging for food.
(Thick Construction 2 ply bags) which are required by code are at least 1.5-3mils thick and are required by code for a reason.
No need to measure the thickness of every bag...
It's very easy to spot the difference by anyone with just minimal training and practice.
Please train those that are payed to enforce the Code to care about the importance of this particular Code. If this Code is rigorously enforced there will be a huge decline in the rodent population and an improvement to the quality of life for the citizens. As well it helps to create and maintain a greener more sustainable environment for all.
Most times these un-contained "kitchen type" bags sit out for 12-15 hrs at a time, twice a week for a total of up to 30 hrs a week? So that's a lot of time for rodents to be feasting on our neighborhood.
Thank you for all the good work from everyone in The Mayors Office and those that we entrust with enforcing Code.
Merry Christmas to all!

description:
I believe there is a Code, specific to "the thickness'" of The plastic bags left out for collection. 
When it comes to the current rodent infestation in this city, it makes sense to me and I'm sure to anybody that happens to read this post that the solution is simple.
Contain trash in "rodent proof" covered containers and the rats go elsewhere to forage for food.
Also containing garbage makes it easier on those workers that pick up the trash and nothing is left behind on the ground after the rodents shred through these very thin kitchen type bags...
If there is a code for the thickness of bags left out in the street then could you please cite the code and educate those that may read this as to what that code actually states.
410.600 is one code that has relevance 
Thank you so much

description:
Hello, I'm on parent council at the Rafael Hernandez. A couple of years ago we had the city put in this traffic slowing sign at the school zone for 20 miles an hour. There have been several incidents recently of near misses with kids being hit by speeding cars up School st. This sign at night is not enough. It is not visible in dark with glare of street light above. The cross walk is not bright enough on the ground either. There is nothing to slow down people during Afterschool times that go up to 6 pm. A speed table/bump or flashing lights to indicate school zone until 6 pm. The current sign only says "when children present." So people may not realize the school is active until around 6 pm. 
Thanks for looking into this safety manner. 
Karen
address: Intersection Of Erie Pl & School St, Jamaica Plain

Thank you Mayor Walsh. 

I attended the Massachusetts Conference for Women. This year it was a solemn event. Nobody talk about the orange elephant in the room. Everyone (including myself) went through the motions with the traditional rhetoric: speak up, fight, support others... without ever really saying anything of substance.

Except for you. You called it out; you called it out loudly and with action.  You discussed the election, you spoke to SIGNIFICANT goals and real programs in existence and the future.

You and only you.

I remember when you talked about how your friend told you how hard it was to get pay equity, and quickly you got it and put in place programs and commitments that are real.

I'm not happy who was elected as our president, but everyday I'm grateful for our mayor. I'm grateful you listen. I'm grateful to wake up in our city.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid responding to a gas leak on your street activated an emergency permit. Emergency work must be performed no matter what time of day or night in the interest of public safety and the protection of private property. This proved to be a very difficult repair, resulting in National Grid working into the night. and plating the job. The emergency has been rectified and National Grid is currently waiting for an excavation permit to finish the job. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work caused. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office. 617-438-8517 Cell.

description:
The intersection of Charter St. and Snow Hill St. is incredibly unfriendly to pedestrians. Pictured you can see a street light pole (which could perhaps be moved slightly up Snow Hill), a street light control box (which sticks far out from the wall, and finally, what appears to be an ancient streetlight post, long replaced.

All in all, it makes the corner nearly impassable. Removing the old post seems like a no-brainer. Adjusting the placement of the streetlight, the control box, or both, is likely more work, but would improve things greatly.
